reviewText: This cartoon is included as a special bonus feature on the Smurfs blu-ray movie. It is an excellent bonus feature that might persuade a buyer to purchase that movie instead of this DVD. It features a mixture of CGI with traditional animation, which nicely blends the classic characters with the current movies.
summary: A Mixture of CGI and Traditional Smurfiness

reviewText: Love that the Smurfs are back!  I grew up watching them in the 80's so I don't like how they have changed the characters somewhat and I don't like the "modern humor" they put in these.  I do LOVE the virtual characters and the Christmas village looks amazing.  It is a good story line and is a good addition to my Christmas movie collection.  My 2.5 year old son loves this movie as well.  It goes from computer characters to animated then back to computer characters.

reviewText: It plays off Dicken's "A Christmas Carol" which has been done before but with Grouchy as Scrooge's replacement.  The film starts and ends with CGI/3D animation, like Smurfy Hollow the rest is traditional.  I'm sure for monetary reasons they can't get the entire cast together but for the characters in this short most are the originals from the movie.  Worth checking out and dropping $1.99 on both holiday features as we paid a premium for Smurfs "Smurfy Hollow" at the local store for $5.99.  Our kids loved the first movie and this was well worth it to add to Instant Video!

reviewText: The Smurfs: A Christmas Carol takes the traditional Charles Dickens story and puts its own smurfy spin on it, having it be about Grouchy and his refusal to celebrate Christmas. It starts off with 3D CGI, but then it shifts to 2D animation when Grouchy gets visited by the three Smurfs of Christmas, played by Smurfette, Brainy, and Hefty in that order. The voices for this special were great, using the actors from the first live-action Smurfs movie with the exception of Papa Smurf (who is voiced by Jack Angel) and Smurfette (who is voiced by Melissa Sturm). The story itself is entertaining, though it's not anything you haven't seen before a hundred other times. The animation is a modern-day improvement over the Smurfs cartoon show specials from the 1980s, having been created by Duck Studios, but isn't so different that fans of the cartoon show can't find themselves enjoying it. Overall it's worth a purchase.
summary: A spiritual successor to the Hanna-Barbera cartoon show
